enu: Page to administer the Activities Feed emails.
Page to view and administer the License.
Page to administer the transformation services.
Page to administer the subscription service.
Page to administer the system settings.
Page to administer the search service.
Page to administer the replication service.
Export detailed system information (JMX dump) to a zip file.
View and administer active user sessions.
View list of applied repository patches.
Users can add content to the repository by email (SMTP). Use the following options to enable (or disable) inbound emails via SMTP and configure who can send them and how they are handled.
See Inbound Email for more details.
Enable or disable the inbound email service.
Specify the user name that the email will be authenticated as if the sender address cannot be matched to an existing user email.

To allow only specified senders enter a comma-separated list of email REGEX patterns, for example: .*\\@hotmail\\.com, .*\\@googlemail\\.com. The sender email address must match a listed value for the message to be accepted.
By default duplicate messages to a folder will overwrite each other. Deselect to number and keep duplicate messages.
The maximum number of connections allowed. Increase this number to prioritize the email subsystem over other subsystems. The default setting is 3.
Enable or disable the authentication of inbound email against the repository.
The port number for the email server. The default is 25.
The default domain for the email server.

To block senders enter a comma-separated list of email REGEX patterns, for example: .*\\@hotmail\\.com, .*\\@googlemail\\.com. If the sender email address matches a listed value, then the message will be rejected.
Users must be a member of this group to add content to the repository by email. The default group is EMAIL_CONTRIBUTORS.

TLS protocol upgrades a plain text connection to an encrypted TLS or SSL connection instead of using a separate port for encrypted communication. Select whether TLS support is enabled, disabled, hidden, or required.
You must configure a Java keystore to enable TLS support for inbound email. See SMTP inbound email using StartTLS for more details.
Hidden: On the EHLO command, server support for TLS is hidden, though TLS will still be accepted if the client uses it.
Enabled: On the EHLO command, server support for TLS is announced.
Email not sent. Please see error description below.

The outbound email service manages and runs all emails sent to users, such as site invites, activity notifications, and workflow tasks. Use the settings on this page to configure outbound email properties.
See Outbound Email for more details.
The name of the SMTP(S) host server.
The email encoding type. The default is UTF-8.

If selected then the From field in outbound emails can be edited to differ from the Default Sender's Address. If deselected then the Default Sender's Address will always be used. You should deselect this option if your email server security settings require the From field to match the user name used for email server authentication.
The port number for the email server. The default is 25.
The default address that is used in the From field of outbound emails if no alternative is available.
Use the settings in this section to select from SMTP and SMTPS as the protocol to be used for outbound email.
Select the protocol to be used when sending email.
The account user name that connects to the SMTP server. The user name and password are only required if your server requires them for authentication.
Use these settings if you selected SMTP as the email protocol.
If enabled, the user name and password entered above will be used for authentication with your remote email server.
Enables Transport Layer Security. This may be required by the remote email server.
Timeout value in milliseconds. The default is 30000.
Enables additional diagnostics for troubleshooting the email connection.
Use these settings if you selected SMTPS as the email protocol.
If enabled, the user name and password entered above will be used for authentication with your remote email server.
Enables Transport Layer Security. This may be required by the remote email server.
These settings define if and how test messages are sent.
Select to send a test message when the outbound email service starts.
The message body of the test message.

Applies a new license that is stored on the file system. Does not apply if the server has a license uploaded to the repository. You may need to restart the server to enable any features added in the new license.
The license was not applied due to an unknown error.

Upload a new license from your browser and apply to the repository. This will take precedence over license files on the file system. You may need to restart the server to enable any features added in the new license.
The license was not uploaded due to an unknown error.
The license was not applied due to an error with the uploaded file.
The license was not applied due to an error with the license file and the existing license has failed to reload.
The license was successfully uploaded and applied to the repository.

Your access and use of Alfresco Content Services is managed by your license. The license sets the maximum number of users and a maximum number of content objects that you can use. The license is not tied to specific servers, for example, by IP or MAC address. You need to purchase and upload licenses appropriate to the number of users, content objects, and your support requirements.
Name of license holder. This should be your company name.
Number of days that your license covers.
Original location where the license was generated.
Date and time when your license will expire.
Number of authorized users that you can have for your license.
Days remaining before your license expires.
Maximum number of content objects that you can have in your Alfresco Content Services system. Content objects are items such as documents and related thumbnails, wiki items, and blog posts.

The current number of users in the system. If the maximum number of users is unlimited then the current users will also be shown as unlimited. If the maximum number of users is updated then the current users may show as pending until the system updates.

The current number of content objects in the system. If the maximum number of objects is unlimited then the current objects will also be shown as unlimited. If the maximum number of objects is updated then the current objects may show as pending until the system updates.
Shows whether your license allows the heartbeat functionality to be disabled. If disabled then automatic repository statistics are not sent.
Shows whether your license allows synchronization to Alfresco Content Services in the Cloud.
Shows whether your license allows clustering.
Shows whether your license allows use of the encrypted content store.

A license is required to run your Alfresco Content Services server once the trial period has expired. You have the option to store your license in the repository or on the file system. Licenses in the repository take precedence over those on the file system.
See Uploading a new license for more details.
Upload a new license from your browser and apply to the repository.
Apply a new license that is stored on the file system. Does not apply if the server has a license uploaded to the repository.

The allowable user limit of {0} as per your license agreement has been exceeded.  There are currently {1} users in the system. Please contact your Alfresco sales representative to purchase additional user licenses.

The allowable user limit of {0} for your license agreement has been reached. There are {1} users in the system, {2} are temporarily permitted. Please contact your Alfresco sales representative to purchase additional user licenses.

The allowable user limit of {0} as per your license agreement is being approached.  There are {1} users in the system. Please contact your Alfresco sales representative to purchase additional user licenses.
The Repository Information shows details of the originally installed repository and the current version. The values will be the same if the system has not been upgraded.
Unique identifier for this repository version.
Unique identifier for this repository version.
The system settings are a combination of your server settings, the Alfresco Content Services repository settings, and the Alfresco Share settings.
These settings can only be changed via the alfresco-global.properties file.
See Command line configuration for more details.
The context path of the Alfresco Content Services web application URL. The default is alfresco.

The externally resolvable hostname of the Alfresco Content Services web application. The default value is ${localname}. If the default value is used the token ${localname} will be automatically replaced by the domain name of the repository server.

The protocol component of the Alfresco Content Services web application. The default is http. HTTPS support requires additional configuration within the host application server - see your application server documentation for details.
The externally resolvable port number of the Alfresco Content Services web application URL. The default is 8080.
Indicates that the repository will allow write operations (provided that the license is valid).

By default, this field is empty and all users can log in. Enter a comma-separated list of users to allow only those users to log in. If a list is entered that does not contain the current user, the current user will be added automatically.
The maximum number of simultaneous users allowed to log in. The default setting of -1 means there are an unlimited number of users allowed.
The context path of the Share web application URL. The default is share.
The externally resolvable host name of the Share web application URL. The default value is ${localname}.
The group name that users need to be a member of to access Public sites. The default is GROUP_EVERYONE which contains all users.

The protocol component of the Share web application. The default is http. HTTPS support requires additional configuration within the host application server - see your application server documentation for details.
The externally resolvable port number of the Share web application URL. The default is 8080.

If enabled, Activities Feed emails are sent to all users, summarizing the activities they see in their My Activities dashlet. Emails include activities in all sites they are a member of, and by people they are following. You can set the frequency with which these emails are sent, the maximum number of activities they contain, and the maximum age of the activities.
Enable/disable activity notifications to users via email.

Specifies a cron expression which defines the frequency with which users will receive Activities Feed emails. Emails are only sent if there are new activities since the last email. By default this is every 24 hours at midnight.
The maximum number of activities that are reported on in the Activities dashlets and Activities Feed emails.
The maximum age of the activities shown in the Activities Feed emails. Activities older than the maximum age are not shown. The default setting is 44640 (a 31-day month).

Cluster validation performs a check to ensure the cluster communcations are working correctly. All cluster members should show success status for a cluster to be considered validated. If one server fails in a two-server cluster, then both will be marked as having failed. Failure usually indicates network connectivity issues between the failing servers.
Clustering is not enabled on this server.
There is only one node in the cluster. Two or more nodes are required to test connectivity.
Servers connected to the same database instance are usually clustered automatically. In most cases no additional configuration is necessary.
See Setting up high availability systems for more details.
The server that you are currently connected to.
Clustering is not enabled on the license.
The server could not be removed from the list.
The host IP or port is missing
See the logs for further details.

Alfresco Content Services servers can be connected to the same database and not be members of the repository cluster. This may be expected when servers are configured for specific situations, such as dedicated indexing servers. If a non-clustered server is listed that should be clustered then there is a problem with the cluster configuration.

To ensure that your index server shard management is successful, you should read the documentation throughly before adding new shard instances or groups.

You can create both individual shards and shard groups. You first need to select one or more target index servers from the existing index servers. You can also create new index servers.

Then enter the properties for the new group or shard.
See Solr sharding for more details.
Enter the index server address. e.g. http://127.0.0.1:8983/solr
Enter properties for the new shard group.
The index servers that will be used for sharding.
The template used for the shard group.
The stores that are queryable for all shards.
The name of the SOLR core.
The properties to set for the Solr instances. These are the same as those in the solrcore.properties file.
Create shards based on the ordered list of target index servers.
Enter properties for one or more new shard instances.
Enter a single index server, for example, localhost:8080/solr4.
The total number of nodes that have been created.
The serial number of the target index server for the new shard.
Enter the specific shards to create. You can also enter a comma-separated list of shards.
See the Alfresco Content Services log files for more details.
We hit a problem creating the shard.
Create default indexes on the servers listed in Target Index Servers.
Update the properties that apply to all Alfresco indexes on an Index Engine.
Shared properties: enter properties and values as follows: param=value.
These are the same as in <>/conf/shared.properties

Shard instances are registered dynamically with an Alfresco Content Services repository or cluster and are formed into queryable shard groups. They're grouped based on common configurations such as the template used to create them and the number of shards. Shard groups can change or break up dynamically for reasons including index servers being created, becoming unreachable, or new shard instances being created and deleted. Shard instances can be dynamically combined in different ways when queried.

Existing shard details are shown here. Click Manage to create new shards and shard groups and to manage index servers.
See Solr sharding for more details.
To use shard groups you need an Alfresco Content Services license that supports clustering.
Clustering is not available with this license.
Select to use dynamic shard instance registration. If not selected then manual shard registration is used.
Purge all persisted dynamic shard instance information at startup.
The number of seconds a shard instance can go without making a tracking call for transactions to the repository before it stops being used for queries.
The maximum number of transactions a shard instance can lag behind the lead instance of the shard before it stops being used for queries.
Remove all registered shard instance information.
Remove inactive registered shard instance information.
The template used for the Solr core.
A list of shards that have less than the maximum instances.
A comma separated list of shards with no instances.
The maximum number of transactions IDs in the repository.
The maximum number of instances available for any shard that can be used to answer a query.
The maximum number of transactions remaining for all the lead instances of all the active shards.
The minimum number of instances available for any shard that can be used to answer a query.
Maximum changeset ID in the repository.
Specifies whether the instances are SLAVE, MASTER or MIXED.
The stores that are queryable for all instances.
This is enabled if content is included for all instances.
The method used to define shards.
This is a text summary of this page. You can copy the content using standard keyboard shortcuts.
See the Alfresco Content Services log files for more details.
The host IP or port is missing.
We hit a problem completing your request.
Workflows run on an embedded workflow engine.
Enabled by default. It is recommended that you do not change this setting.
Select whether the Activiti process definitions are available to users.

You can automatically replicate folders and content between repositories by using replication jobs. These jobs are controlled by the replication service, which finds content that needs to be replicated and then calls the transfer service to carry out the replication.
See Setting up replication jobs for more information.
Use these settings to enable/disable the replication capabilities and control read/write permissions.
Enable/disable the ability to replicate content from this repository.

By default, any replicated content is read-only in the target repository. This ensures the integrity of the content is not compromised by uncontrolled updates. Only disable this option for specific use cases.
You can select which search service to use, and manage and monitor your service. Alfresco Content Services supports the use of the Solr Enterprise search platform for searching within the repository.
See Solr Overview for more details.
Select which search service to use.
Properties may not be displayed correctly as the search system is currently restarting. Please refresh the page to display these properties.
Select to enable Solr to connect to the server and track and index updates.
The application server http port (non-secure) that Solr is running on. This is only used if Solr is configured to run without secure communications.
Hostname the Solr server is running on. Use localhost if running on the same machine.
The application server https port that Solr is running on.
The base URL for the Solr web application - normally /solr.
Select to enable Solr Auto Suggest.
This section provides information on the status of the Solr index tracker for the Main (Workspace) Store.
Indicates whether Solr is currently indexing outstanding transactions.
The transaction ID most recently indexed by Solr.
Estimated time that Solr will take to complete indexing the current outstanding transactions.
Disk space used by the latest version of the SOLR index. Allow at least double this value for background indexing management.
Time that indexing is currently behind the repository updates.
Estimated number of outstanding transactions that require indexing.
Current memory usage. Note: This value may vary due to transient memory used by background processing. The value does not include Lucene related caches.
This section provides information on the status of the Solr index tracker for the Archive store.
Indicates whether Solr is currently indexing outstanding transactions.
The transaction ID most recently indexed by Solr.
Estimated time that Solr will take to complete indexing the current outstanding transactions.
Disk space used by the latest version of the SOLR index. Allow at least double this value for background indexing management.
Time that indexing is currently behind the repository updates.
Estimated number of outstanding transactions that require indexing.
Current memory usage. Note: This value may vary due to transient memory used by background processing. The value does not include Lucene related caches.
The location where the index backup is stored on the Solr server.
A unix-like expression, using the same syntax as the cron command, that defines when backups occur. The default value is 0 0 2 * * ? meaning the backup is performed daily at 02.00.
The number of backups to keep (including the latest backup).
The location where the index backup is stored on the Solr server.
A unix-like expression, using the same syntax as the cron command, that defines when backups occur. The default value is 0 0 4 * * ? meaning the backup is performed daily at 04.00.
The number of backups to keep (including the latest backup).
Solr can still track with NoIndex search enabled. This setting may be used to disable Solr tracking by separate Solr instance(s) configured to track this server.

The database can be used to support a subset of CMIS Query Language and Alfresco Full Text Search. For each of these services you can select a default mode which defines if and when the database should be used.
Never use Database: The database is not used for the query, the configured search service will always be used.
Always use Database: Queries will always be executed using the database. If the query contains predicates or operators not supported by database query, the query will fail.
Use Database if possible: The database will be used if the query contains supported predicates and operators, otherwise it will fall back to the configured search service.
Hybrid (SOLR and Database): The configured search service will be used first. If this is SOLR then the database will be used to retrieve results not yet indexed by the SOLR service.

See Transactional Metadata Query for more details.

For upgrades, a patch must be applied before these options are available, see Configuring an optional patch for upgrade.

You can keep track of other users activities by choosing to follow them. When users are being followed, the person(s) following them will receive activity notifications. The Subscription Service is the underlying service used to manage and generate activity notifications. You can use this page to enable/disable the Subscription Service and the follow feature on a system wide basis..

This option is selected by default. It allows users to follow other users and then filter activities according to who they are following. If you disable subscriptions, users will not be able to follow other users or see their activities.

Transformation services let you convert content between different file formats. The JODConverter installation (part of OpenOffice.org) is used by Alfresco Content Services for document transformations, such as a text file to PDF. The ImageMagick installation is used for image transformations and it is recommended that you do not change their settings.
Select to enable JODConverter based transformations.
The maximum number of tasks that can be performed concurrently.
The maximum number of milliseconds that an operation is allowed to run before it is aborted. The default is 120000 milliseconds (2 minutes).
The location of the office suite installation used for JODConverter transformations. This can be OpenOffice.org or LibreOffice.
The port number that JODConverter uses. To enable multiple process instances enter a comma-separated list of port numbers, all of which must be available.
The maximum number of milliseconds a task waits in the transformation queue before the process restarts. The default is 30000 milliseconds (30 seconds).
View current active sessions on the system.

You can use this screen to end a user's Alfresco session. Clients such as Alfresco Share will automatically log the user back into the repository if the client has cached valid authentication details.
Ignore this thread: this is the running process to Obtain HOTTHREADS
Generates a report of the 5 most active threads on the system and their CPU usage.
Provides information about the thread dump.
Ignore this thread: this is the running process to Obtain HOTTHREADS
Click a thread to see the stack trace. You can group threads by ID, name, status, memory allocated or percentage of CPU time.
Same stacktrace as previous Thread Dump
Provides information about the thread sampler.
Click the thread status to see the stack trace. You can save information to view later.
Same stacktrace as the previous thread dump

Changes to JMX attributes persist after you restart Alfresco Content Services. Changes to JMX levels apply to all cluster servers that you are currently connected to. If a setting is changed using JMX, the equivalent value set in your global properties file is ignored. Use this page to find settings and to revert to any values set in your global properties file.
Export detailed system information (JMX dump) to a zip file.
Displays the last lines of the log file.
Changes to log levels using this page are temporary and do not persist after you restart the system. Changes to the log levels apply to the server that you are currently connected to.
View patches that have been applied.
Manually run a scheduled job. This won't be shown as a PreviousFireTime with automated runs.
{0} operation successful, see the log files for further details.
The scheduled job couldn't be run, see the log files for further details.
Select Export to download a zip file containing information for troubleshooting and supporting your system.
Export detailed system information (JMX dump) to a zip file.
Operation unsuccessful, see the log files for further details.
Lists the latest entries in the transformation debug log
Lists the latest entries in the transformation log
Lists the names of all top level transformers
Testing tranformation using: {0} from: {1} to: {2} context: {3}
Transformation by extension  from: {0} to: {1} context: {2}
There isn't an operation parameter selected in the URL.
Export information about the transformation system settings.
Lists all transformer properties that are set.
Adds or replaces transformer properties. To clear a custom value, set its value back to the default. To remove a custom property, use the Remove Properties button.
Removes transformer properties. Enter the Property Name to be removed. Only custom properties should be removed.
Lists the latest entries in the transformation log.
Lists the latest entries in the transformation debug log.
Lists the names of all top level transformers.
Lists the transformation statistics for the current node.
Transforms a small test file from one MIME type to another and then shows the debug of the transform.  Results show if the transform was successful.
Lists all possible transformations sorted by source and then target mimetype extension.
Lists all possible transformations sorted by transformer name. If blank, all transformers are included.
Transformer Name to be checked. If blank all transformers are included.
Source extension to be checked. If blank, all source MIME types are included.
Target extension to be checked. If blank, all target MIME types are included.
How the transformation will be used.
Use or context in which the transformation will be used.

The external authentication subsystem can be used to integrate Alfresco Content Services with any external authentication system. It can be integrated with your application server so that the identity of the logged-in user is passed to servlets via the HttpServletRequest.getRemoteUser() method. As this is the standard way for application servers to propagate user identities to servlets, it is compatible with a number of SSO solutions, including Central Authentication Service (CAS).
See Configuring external authentication for more details.

Select to enable external directory user authentication. When enabled, Alfresco Content Services accepts external authentication tokens; ensure that no untrusted direct access to Alfresco Content Services HTTP or AJP ports is allowed.

The remote user that is considered the proxy user. The default is alfresco-system. Requests made by this user are made under the identity of the user named in the proxy header indicated by the external.authentication.proxyHeader property. If not set, then the proxy header is always assumed to carry the user name.
The HTTP header that carries the name of a proxied user. The default is X-Alfresco-Remote-User.
If required, enter a comma separated list of user names to be considered administrators by default.

An optional regular expression to be used to extract a user ID from the HTTP header. The portion of the header matched by the first bracketed group in the regular expression will become the user name. If not set then the entire header contents are assumed to be the proxied user name.

Internal authentication is configured by default in the authentication chain. Authentication is based on user and password information stored in the repository. This authentication is capable of supporting form-based login.
See Configuring Authentication for more details.
If selected authentication for FTP access is enabled.

The Java Authentication and Authorization Service (JAAS) is used within the Kerberos subsystem to support Kerberos authentication of user names and passwords. You can choose to use Kerberos against an Active Directory server in preference to LDAP as it provides strong encryption without using SSL. It is possible to export user registry information using a chained LDAP subsystem.
Additional configuration is required to set up Kerberos. See Configuring Kerberos for more details.
The entry in the JAAS configuration file that should be used for password-based authentication. The default value Alfresco is recommended.
When selected the @domain suffix is stripped from Kerberos authenticated usernames in SPP, WebDAV, and the Web Client. If not selected then multi-domain users can use the @domain suffix.
If required, enter a comma separated list of user names to be considered administrators by default.
The Kerberos realm used for authentication. The realm should be the domain in upper case, for example if the domain is alfresco.org then the realm should be ALFRESCO.ORG.
The entry in the JAAS configuration file used for web-based single-sign on (SSO). The default value AlfrescoHTTP is recommended.
The password for the HTTP Kerberos principal.
If selected kerberos authentication for FTP access is enabled.

An LDAP subsystem can be used for user authentication and user and group registry synchronization (export). These functions can be used in isolation or in combination. LDAP is highly configurable but generally requires few changes as the defaults are set for a typical set up. Only one LDAP connection can be configured here.
See Configuring LDAP for detailed information on configuring authentication.
It is generally recommended that you do not change these settings.
If selected, the LDAP directory will be used to authenticate users. If the LDAP directory is only to be used for synchronization then this should be deselected.

Defines how the user-entered Alfresco ID is passed through to LDAP. If no value is entered (the default for the LDAP subsystem), an LDAP query resolves the Distinguished Name (DN) from the user ID dynamically. This allows directories to be structured and does not require the user ID to appear in the DN. Entering a value restricts LDAP user names to a fixed format, where the placeholder %s in the value is replaced with the entered user ID to produce the ID passed to LDAP - see LDAP configuration properties for further details.
The URL of your LDAP server, containing its name and port. The standard ports for LDAP are 389 (and 636 for SSL)
If required, enter a comma separated list of user names to be considered administrators by default. If you are using LDAP for all your users, this maps an LDAP user to be an administrator user.
Select a security mechanism to use to authenticate with the LDAP server. The recommended values are simple and DIGEST-MD5.
If selected, the LDAP directory will permit user and group synchronization. If the LDAP directory is only to be used for authentication then this should be deselected.

The LDAP user to connect as for synchronization, if one is required by the synchronization authentication mechanism. This is the same format as the LDAP User Name Format but with a real user ID instead of %s. This account is used to retrieve the details of all users and groups in the directory so that it can synchronize its internal user and authority database. When Security is set to simple the default is cn=Manager,dc=company,dc=com.
This query selects all objects that represent the groups to synchronize. This query is used in full synchronization mode, which by default is scheduled every 24 hours.
The DN that user queries start from.
This query selects all objects that represent the users to synchronize. This query is used in full synchronization mode, which by default is scheduled every 24 hours.
Select a security mechanism to use to authenticate with the LDAP synchronization server. The recommended values are simple and DIGEST-MD5.
The password for the Security Principal Name, if required. This is only used for LDAP synchronization.
The DN that group queries start from.

Used in differential synchronization mode whenever a user is successfully authenticated that doesn't exist yet in Alfresco Content Services. The query selects users to synchronize that have changed since a specified time period. The placeholder {0} is used in place of the Timestamp format in the LDAP Synchronization Advanced Settings.
Defines how the home space is created for users created through synchronization.
Used whenever a group is successfully authenticated that doesn't exist yet. The query selects users to synchronize that have changed since a specified time period.
The name of the attribute in LDAP group objects that should be mapped to the group name, by default, cn.
The name of the group type in LDAP, by default, groupOfNames.
The name of the person type in LDAP, by default, inetOrgPerson.
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the email address property.
The attribute name on people objects found in LDAP to use as the UID.
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the organizational id  property in Alfresco Content Services.

If set to a positive integer, this property indicates that RFC 2696 paged results should be used to split query results into batches of the specified size. This overcomes any size limits imposed by the LDAP server. If set to 0 or less, paged results will not be used.
The name of the attribute in LDAP group objects that should be mapped to the group display name, by default, description.
The name of the attribute in LDAP group objects that defines the DN for its members.
The name of the operational attribute recording the last update time for a group or user.
The timestamp format. For OpenLDAP use yyyyMMddHHmmss'Z'.
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the first name property.
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the lastName property.
If selected ldap authentication for FTP access is enabled.
A list of space-separated authentication types of connections that may be pooled. Valid types are "none", "simple", and "DIGEST-MD5".
A string that indicates the level of debug output to produce. Valid values are "fine" (trace connection creation and removal) and "all" (all debugging information).
The string representation of an integer that represents the number of connections per connection identity to create when initially creating a connection for the identity.
The string representation of an integer that represents the maximum number of connections per connection identity that can be maintained concurrently. Empty value means no maximum size.
The string representation of an integer that represents the preferred number of connections per connection identity that should be maintained concurrently. Empty value means no preferred size.
A list of space-separated protocol types of connections that may be pooled. Valid types are "plain" and "ssl".

The string representation of an integer that represents the number of milliseconds that an idle connection may remain in the pool without being closed and removed from the pool. Empty value means no timeout, connection stays in pool forever. Bad connections are automatically detected and removed from the pool by the LDAP provider
The string representation of an integer that represents the number of milliseconds to specify how long to wait for a pooled connection. Empty value means the application will wait indefinitely.

An LDAP-AD subsystem can be used for user authentication and user and group registry synchronization (export). These functions can be used in isolation or in combination. LDAP-AD is highly configurable but generally requires few changes as the defaults are set for a typical set up. Only one LDAP-AD connection can be configured here.
See Configuring LDAP for detailed information on configuring authentication.
It is generally recommended that you do not change these settings.
If selected, the LDAP directory will be used to authenticate users. If the LDAP directory is only to be used for synchronization then this should be deselected.

Defines how the user-entered ID is passed through to LDAP. If no value is entered (the default for the LDAP subsystem), an LDAP query resolves the Distinguished Name (DN) from the user ID dynamically. This allows directories to be structured and does not require the user ID to appear in the DN. Entering a value restricts LDAP user names to a fixed format, where the placeholder %s in the value is replaced with the entered user ID to produce the ID passed to LDAP - see LDAP configuration properties for further details.
The URL of your LDAP server, containing its name and port. The standard ports for LDAP are 389 (and 636 for SSL)
If required, enter a comma separated list of user names to be considered administrators by default. If you are using LDAP for all your users, this maps an LDAP user to be an administrator user.
Select a security mechanism to use to authenticate with the LDAP server. The recommended values are simple and DIGEST-MD5.
If selected, the LDAP directory will permit user and group synchronization. If the LDAP directory is only to be used for authentication then this should be deselected.

The LDAP user to connect as for synchronization, if one is required by the synchronization authentication mechanism. This is the same format as the LDAP User Name Format but with a real user ID instead of %s. This account is used to retrieve the details of all users and groups in the directory so that it can synchronize its internal user and authority database. When Security is set to simple the default is cn=Manager,dc=company,dc=com.
This query selects all objects that represent the groups to synchronize. This query is used in full synchronization mode, which by default is scheduled every 24 hours.
The DN that user queries start from.
This query selects all objects that represent the users to synchronize. This query is used in full synchronization mode, which by default is scheduled every 24 hours.
Select a security mechanism to use to authenticate with the LDAP synchronization server. The recommended values are simple and DIGEST-MD5.
The password for the Security Principal Name, if required. This is only used for LDAP synchronization.
The DN that group queries start from.

Used in differential synchronization mode whenever a user is successfully authenticated that does not yet exist. The query selects users to synchronize that have changed since a specified time period. The placeholder {0} is used in place of the Timestamp format in the LDAP Synchronization Advanced Settings.
Defines how the home space is created for users created through synchronization.
Used whenever a group is successfully authenticated that doesn't exist yet. The query selects users to synchronize that have changed since a specified time period.
The name of the attribute in LDAP group objects that should be mapped to the group name, by default, cn
The name of the group type in LDAP, by default, groupOfNames
The name of the person type in LDAP, by default, inetOrgPerson
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the email address property
The attribute name on people objects found in LDAP to use as the UID
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the organizational ID property.

If set to a positive integer, this property indicates that RFC 2696 paged results should be used to split query results into batches of the specified size. This overcomes any size limits imposed by the LDAP server. If set to 0 or less, paged results will not be used.
The name of the attribute in LDAP group objects that should be mapped to the group display name, by default, description.
The name of the attribute in LDAP group objects that defines the DN for its members
The name of the operational attribute recording the last update time for a group or user.
The timestamp format. For LDAP Active Directory use yyyyMMddHHmmss'.0Z'
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the lastName property
The attribute on person objects in LDAP to map to the lastName property in Alfresco Content Services

If positive, this property indicates that range retrieval should be used to fetch multi-valued attributes (such as member) in batches of the specified size. Overcomes any size limits imposed by Active Directory.
If selected ldap authentication for FTP access is enabled.
A list of space-separated authentication types of connections that may be pooled. Valid types are "none", "simple", and "DIGEST-MD5".
A string that indicates the level of debug output to produce. Valid values are "fine" (trace connection creation and removal) and "all" (all debugging information).
The string representation of an integer that represents the number of connections per connection identity to create when initially creating a connection for the identity.
The string representation of an integer that represents the maximum number of connections per connection identity that can be maintained concurrently. Empty value means no maximum size.
The string representation of an integer that represents the preferred number of connections per connection identity that should be maintained concurrently. Empty value means no preferred size.
A list of space-separated protocol types of connections that may be pooled. Valid types are "plain" and "ssl".

The string representation of an integer that represents the number of milliseconds that an idle connection may remain in the pool without being closed and removed from the pool. Empty value means no timeout, connection stays in pool forever. Bad connections are automatically detected and removed from the pool by the LDAP provider
The string representation of an integer that represents the number of milliseconds to specify how long to wait for a pooled connection. Empty value means the application will wait indefinitely.
Reset this directory back to its initial settings.
WARNING: You will lose all changes you have made to this directory since it was created. Please ensure you have a copy of the settings for future reference.
The synchronization settings manage the synchronization of Alfresco Content Services with all the user registries (LDAP servers) in the authentication chain.
See Configuring synchronization for more details.

Select to run synchronization on system startup. This ensures that when user registries are first configured, the bulk of the synchronization work is done on server startup, rather than on the first login.
Select to run synchronization when a user is successfully authenticated who doesn't exist yet.
If selected then local users and groups can be deleted during synchronisation when handling removals or collision resolution.

The number of user or group entries processed during synchronization before progress is logged at INFO level. This requires the following default entry in log4j.properties: log4j.logger.org.alfresco.repo.security.sync=info. The default is 100.

If selected, then a user with default properties is created whenever a user who doesn't exist yet is successfully authenticated, but is not found in synchronization. If not selected this allows you to restrict Alfresco Content Services to a subset of those users who could be authenticated by LDAP, and only those created by synchronization are allowed to log in. You can control the set of users in this more restricted set by overriding the user query properties of the LDAP authentication subsystem.
Select to run differential sync, deselect to run full sync. Regardless of this setting a differential sync may still be triggered when a user is successfully authenticated who doesn't exist yet.
Specifies a cron expression which defines when the scheduled synchronization job should run. By default this is every 24 hours at midnight.
The number of worker threads used for synchronization. The default is 1.
A username and password from the target directory is required to run a full set of tests.

You can manage users and groups internally and/or configure authentication and synchronization from multiple external directory servers. The order of the directories listed (the authentication chain) reflects the priority order in which they will be used to authenticate and synchronize users and groups. It is recommended that each user only exists in a single directory.
See Alfresco Authentication and Security for more details.
External authentication type can only appear once in the chain.
Settings are common to all directories for which synchronization is enabled.
Starts the user directory sync of all users and groups.

Use the up and down arrows to reorder the authentication chain. Some other authentication mechanisms cannot be chained - see Authentication subsystem types for details of authentication types supplied with Alfresco.
If you have an "External" authentication type this will always appear as the first item in the chain.

Select SPENGO directory to automatically log users in via a browser, or select to disable automatic login. Other forms of Single Sign-On can be configured using the External authentication type such as CAS or Siteminder. See Configuring Alfresco Share to use an external SSO for more details.
If you are using FTP it will be authenticated using the directory chain defined above. FTP does not support external authentication.
The authentication chain has been modified. Changes to the chain must be saved before new items can be edited or items can be made available for Browser Based Automatic Login.
Starts the user directory sync of all users and groups.
Read Only User Directory Sync Test.   Tests whether data can be read from the specified user directory.
Synchronization is not active (test will still run)
Alfresco Content Services supports access via FTP protocol. You can use this page to enable/disable this service and configure how it operates.
The name given to the file system when using WebDAV or FTP.
Enables or disables the FTP server.
The port that the FTP server listens for connections on.
The upper limit of the range of data ports.
The lower limit of the range of data ports.
The IP address of the front facing (public) FTP Load Balancer server
The IMAP server allows email applications that support IMAP to connect to and interact with repositories directly from the mail client. The IMAP service can listen on either IMAP, IMAPS or both.
Default TO field used when TO field is not available e.g. when displaying documents.
The host or IP address the IMAP service will bind to.
Default FROM field used when FROM field is not available e.g. when displaying documents.
The port number this service will listen on, usually 143.
The port number this service will listen on, usually 993.
Users and Groups (Authorities in Default Zone)
